body: Across Brooklyn over the last year, battles for change and preservation rippled through the borough from Red Hook to Dead Horse Bay, in strikingly grass-roots fashion. The neighborhood crusades were large and small, the issues profound and esthetic. There were victories and defeats and, for some, nebulous results. But whatever the outcome of the
title: A Ripple of Neighborhood Crusades on Issues of All Kinds

body: The Rev. Dr. David Munroe Cory died on Wednesday, having spent many of his 93 years embracing socialism, preaching to American Indians in their own tongue and generally dashing any notion that he was a blue-blooded Presbyterian. Dr. Cory, who had recently suffered a stroke, died of pneumonia at the Norwegian Christian Home in Sunset Park, Brooklyn,
title: The Rev. Dr. David M. Cory, 93, Preacher of Social Reform

body: Asked just a year ago whether they would have supported legislation to severely curtail the power of community school boards, many parents and teachers in District 15 in Brooklyn would have answered loudly in the negative. The district, which straddles working-class neighborhoods in South Brooklyn and more affluent brownstone blocks in Park Slope,
title: In South Brooklyn, Guarded Desire for Change

body: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew will be able to use his new power to hire school superintendents almost immediately in 27 of the city's 32 school districts. The timing of the legislation enacted yesterday coincides with the final months of three-year contracts between all the local school boards and their district superintendents. Five local school
title: Timing Allows Crew To Respond Quickly

body: FUZZY arches of red, white and green garlands graced Fifth Avenue, a street whose name evokes images of packed sidewalks and stores. Tony? You bet. He's in there somewhere, probably walking right past Tiffany. Or Sean, Juan or Chan. This Fifth's in Brooklyn. It is the main street of Sunset Park, home to some 500 small businesses serving an
title: A Main Street Fights to Keep Local Flavor

body: NEW YORK Sharp Drop in New Citizens At a time when immigrants are seeking citizenship at a record pace, the number who are being naturalized in New York City, one of the nation's immigrant meccas, has dropped precipitously since October. $(Page 1.$) For Pedestrians, Little Help Nearly four years after receiving about $50 million in Federal money to
title: Metro Digest

author: Martin Filler writes about architecture for House Beautiful magazine and The New York Review of Books.
body: AS SHE PARKED HER RED Volvo station wagon on a busy shopping street in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn the other day, Jerrilynn D. Dodds, wearing a putty-colored Armani jacket, looked for all the world like a well-heeled hostess venturing into an ethnic neighborhood in search of exotic recipe ingredients. But when she flipped on a voluminous
title: Facets of Islam Refracted in a New York Lens

body: In the five years that he has been commuting on the Gowanus Expressway, John Jennings has always allowed an extra half-hour for the congestion on what some consider the worst road in America. Yesterday, he needed closer to an hour. It was the first day of a 13-month project that officials had warned would turn the Gowanus into a virtual parking lot
title: From Bad to Worse: Going Is Slow as Repairs Begin on the Gowanus

body: NEW YORK Big Givers Fill Giuliani Coffers Mayor Giuliani's aggressive style of political fund-raising for his re-election has produced an unusually high reliance on big givers, with an average campaign contribution of $1,122. That figure is nearly eight times the size of a contribution his leading competitor receives and the highest average gift in
title: Metro Digest

body: A woman and her 11-month-old son died when a fast-moving fire engulfed their apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, fire officials said. Three housemates, who were critically injured, survived by jumping out the windows of their third-story apartment. The early-morning fire, which destroyed the top two floors of a three-story row house at 454 48th
title: Woman and Infant Die In a Brooklyn Fire

body: The year was 1960. Chubby Checker was doing the Twist, that good-looking Senator Jack Kennedy was headed for the White House, and Carmen Bilbao, a 20-year-old student at New York University, walked to a movie in Times Square. ''It was a better time,'' she now recalls. ''I thought it was safe.'' Then, in the old Apollo Theater on West 42d Street,
title: In Pickpocket's Stash, a Peek at Life in 60's

body: A woman and her 11-month-old son died early yesterday morning when a fast-moving fire engulfed their apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, fire officials said. Three housemates, who were critically injured, survived by jumping out the windows of their third-story apartment. The fire, which destroyed the top two floors of a three-story row house at
title: Mother and Baby Die in Brooklyn Fire

body: THE history of the Sunset Park community of Brooklyn is a tale of the effect of waves of immigration on community life. In the 1990's, the tale is being retold with new twists. One has been brought about by the arrival of Chinese immigrants from Hong Kong and the mainland in what has come to be known as the Brooklyn Chinatown, which also embraces
title: Immigrants Again Renew Sunset Park

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract. MANHATTAN CHELSEA $380,000 575 Sixth Avenue (16th St.) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft. recently renovated co-op in a loft building; elevator, dining area, 13-ft. ceilings, h/w
title: Residential Resales

body: In the face of an emotional volley of criticism from parents, teachers and politicians, members of Community School Board 15 voted Wednesday to invite educators to apply for the job of district superintendent. The 5-to-3 vote by the board, with one abstention, effectively ends the nine-year tenure of Superintendent William Casey, who is widely
title: Vote Underlines District Split

body: During a typical evening rush hour at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, the traffic police wrestle with cars backed up for six blocks. All around them, the area is teeming with office workers heading home, parents buying groceries and teen-agers cruising. It is evidence that Downtown Brooklyn is outgrowing itself. Chronic traffic congestion has
title: For Downtown Traffic, Growing Pains May Turn Critical

body: Even as the political battle over the future of superstores in New York City grew heated and occasionally rancorous last week, executives at Price Costco, a major name in warehouse stores, congratulated themselves for opening two new stores in Brooklyn and Queens, where sales easily matched expectations. More than 12,000 people streamed through the
title: Taking Sides in the Superstore Fight

body: As the dispute over the future of superstores in New York City continued to boil at City Hall, one of the biggest of the so-called warehouse stores, Costco, opened its doors in Queens yesterday, selling food and household goods in bulk at low prices. And judging by the crowds, New Yorkers appeared eager to welcome the store, a staple of suburban
title: As Debate Over Megastores Rages, One Opens in Queens

body: Plans for Thanksgiving Food purveyors have come up with new items to vary the Thanksgiving menu. Kitchen, at 218 Eighth Avenue (21st Street), in Chelsea, has smoky chile corn-bread croutons for making stuffing, at $3.95 for 5 ounces. Seasonal smoked turkey and cranberry sausages, from the Aidell's Sausage Company, are $4.99 for 13 ounces at Fairway
title: Food Notes

body: It was Michael Hanly's grin on the recruitment poster that beckoned new employees to the New York City Sanitation Department. ''We need good people,'' the sign read. ''Join the best.'' Hundreds of men and women answered, seeking steady work, good pay and reliable benefits as members of the often overlooked army that keeps the city humming by
title: A Death Reminds Sanitation Force of Its Unseen Hazards

body: For years, residents of western Brooklyn have dreaded the upcoming reconstruction of the Gowanus Expressway, a project that would swamp neighborhoods with traffic for at least five years. But an alternative may be emerging: replacing the crumbling elevated expressway with an underground highway. Ultimately, the most important question is whether
title: As Unpopular Gowanus Overhaul Looms, a Tunnel Plan Gains Notice

body: Eileen C. Dugan, a Brooklyn Democrat who was elected to her ninth term in the New York State Assembly only on Tuesday, died yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center. Ms. Dugan, who lived in Carroll Gardens, was 51. The cause was breast cancer, according to her family. Gov. George E. Pataki, who served in the Assembly with Ms. Dugan, ordered state
title: Eileen C. Dugan, 51, State Assemblywoman

body: In a new tactic to combat organized crime's influence at New York City's five major wholesale food markets, the Giuliani administration wants the authority to investigate and ban officials of unions who represent market employees and are suspected of having ties to the mob. The administration's request is contained in the draft of a proposed law
title: Mayor Seeks to End Link Of Mob to Food Markets

body: For nearly nine years, as superintendent of Community School District 15, William Casey acquired a reputation for raising test scores and securing outside grants. Now a majority on the newly -elected school board has agreed to solicit applications for his job. Instead of renewing his three-year contract when it expires next June, five of nine board
title: School District 15, Shockwaves Over an October Surprise

body: A New York State Supreme Court justice upheld the new city ordinance intended to restrict X-rated businesses yesterday, denying a request from store owners to block the law, which takes effect on Saturday. The store owners said they would appeal immediately and try to stop enforcement. But the decision clears the way for the city to begin the
title: NEW YORK ZONING AGAINST SEX SHOPS IS UPHELD AS FAIR

body: SUNSET PARK On Saturday Only, E Unum Pluribus More than 50 nations are represented in the ethnic mix of Sunset Park, Brooklyn, and flags will be waved to celebrate that diversity on Saturday in the third annual ''Parade of Flags'' up Fifth Avenue. More than 100 flags were waved in last year's parade, as more than 400 people joined the procession
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: MAKING IT WORK 3 Bob Dole's Brooklyn. NEW YORKERS & CO. 4 Pierre Constant, 12, violin virtuoso, faces questions of classical music and race. SHOPPING AROUND 13 Sample sale season has arrived. MOVIE CLOCK 15 What's showing at the local movie houses, today through Thursday. PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD 16 A parade of flags in Sunset Park; writers and
title: ALSO INSIDE

body: A New York City narcotics detective was arrested yesterday and charged with being part of a violent drug-trafficking group that staged a fatal attempted robbery of another dealer and an armored-car robbery that left a guard dead. While Federal authorities said they had no evidence that other members of the police force had been involved with the
title: Narcotics Detective Charged As Part of Drug-Dealing Group

body: The city law intended to restrict X-rated businesses takes effect in just over a week, but most of New York's 180 adult-entertainment establishments are making no plans to move or close. Most of them have joined the New York Civil Liberties Union in a lawsuit to block the law, arguing that it violates constitutional guarantees of free speech and
title: Sex Shops Greet Law With Wink, Nod and Lawsuit

body: Benefit Auction Decorators Walk, D & D Building, 979 Third Avenue (58th Street); (212) 319-7100. An auction of six one-of-a-kind chairs and 25 pillows, all in fabrics from Decorators Walk, will take place tonight at 6:30 P.M., to benefit Furnish a Future, the furniture-donation program of the Partnership for the Homeless. Tickets, including a
title: Calendar: Benefits, Exhibitions And Tours

author: Jane H. Lii contributed to this article.
body: On a corner of Clinton near Delancey, up a narrow stairway between a pawnshop and a Dominican restaurant, Ana Nunez and her three children live in a single, illegal room that suffocates their dreams of a future. It is a $350-a-month rectangle, with no sink and no toilet, that throbs at night with the restaurant's merengue music. Ms. Nunez's
title: For Poor, Life 'Trapped in a Cage'

body: From afar, the religious rally at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park seemed like any other outdoor gospel concert. About 150 gathered to hold hands, shake tambourines and erupt with praiseful shouts of ''Hallelujah!'' But at a closer look, there were some incongruities. For one, the music was in Spanish, and the worshipers were mostly Hispanic
title: Young, Charismatic, Catholic

body: A Federal judge who has been asked to order new primary elections because of ballot problems that kept many voters away from the polls in Brooklyn said that in at least one race, he may instead reopen the polls so that people who did not vote can do so. Many voters could not cast ballots on Sept. 10 because many of the voting machines were not
title: U.S. Judge May Reopen Primary Polls

body: A Federal judge said yesterday that the widespread foul-ups in last week's primary elections in Brooklyn had interfered with many people's right to vote, and he assailed the system that led to the failures. The remarks by Judge David G. Trager of Federal District Court in Brooklyn heartened lawyers for losing candidates in a dozen legislative and
title: Judge Attacks Ballot System's Failures

body: A day after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threatened to scuttle a plan to use thousands of welfare recipients to clean subways and buses, transit officials said they were determined to avoid a public feud with him and were confident he would eventually agree to the plan. Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials, speaking on condition of
title: Objections Aside, Transit Officials Predict Mayoral Support on Workfare

body: Just Like Mexico Su Casa Mexicana, a bakery and food shop at 695 Ninth Avenue (48th Street), would not be out of place in Oaxaca, Mexico. Customers can take a tray and tongs and help themselves to an array of eggy, flaky, custard-filled and almond-scented pastries (75 cents to $1.50 each). Big sugared doughnuts, chilies, packaged foods and homemade
title: Food Notes

body: Two members of a Brooklyn street gang were arrested on murder charges yesterday in connection with a drive-by shooting that left one man dead and five wounded on the Fourth of July, the police said. Kelly Penaloza, 25, was shot and killed when several gunmen, whom the police said were among the several dozen members of the Netas, one of the larger
title: Two Are Charged In Shooting Spree

body: This was when Nydia M. Velazquez had expected to hit her stride. After staking out a position as a vocal spokeswoman on issues like immigration and housing, the two-term Congresswoman had hoped to establish herself this year as a major Congressional player. Instead, this has been a year filled with frustration as Ms. Velazquez, the first Puerto
title: With Redistricting in Vogue, Velaquez Takes a Spot in Line

author: Peter Hellman, an author of five books, frequently writes about New York City for New York magazine and other publications.
body: IF New Yorkers tend to ignore their city's history, it's not entirely their fault. In the daily dash forward, who has time to look back? Who even knows where or how? Yet it can be done, and pleasantly. Forget the car and take the BMT to 25th Street in Brooklyn. Ignore the drab environs of workaday Sunset Park as you exit onto Fourth Avenue. Walk a
title: Where History Is at Rest

body: New York City sends more than 60 legislators to the State Assembly, but most do not face difficult races this November, and only a few will be opposed in next Tuesday's primaries. Here are the more serious contests. 36th District (Queens): Democratic primary. Denis Butler, 69, has represented this Astoria-based district for 20 years. Although we
title: The Assembly Primaries

body: Four Brooklyn garment factories, including one that produced clothing for a line that Kmart sells under the Kathy Ireland label, have been raided by law enforcement officials, and their owners and managers have been arrested for operating sweatshops, the Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday. One of the factories, at 900 60th Street in Sunset
title: 'Sweatshop' Again Tied To Celebrity

body: The Father of Chinantla has no doorbell, but then he is rarely at home. The easiest way to find the elder statesman of ''La Quince,'' as the Mexicans who live on and around 15th Avenue call their neighborhood, is to pop into a bodega on 36th Street and say, ''Margarito?'' When the inquiry was made one recent evening, the response from the clerk was
title: Far From His Mexican Town, He's Still the Town Father

body: LAST winter, Hao Ci Chen saw dress shirts all around him -- piles of them inside a noisy, windowless Brooklyn sweatshop, where he earned a penny for every dangling string he cut from each button. It wasn't a great job, but as is the case with many of his friends, it was all Hao Ci, a 14-year-old Chinese immigrant, could find in Sunset Park. At
title: Immigrant Finds Hope In Bank's Calm

body: LUCKY LUCIANO'S mug shots are there. So are front and side views of the rest of the old Murder Inc. crime syndicate. Calling cards from Victorian-era call girls promise ''the French treatment'' at an address on Chrystie Street. A yellowed parchment from 1718 is an invoice from New York City's official ''Publick Wipper,'' for his salary of 3 pounds,
title: Rummaging in the City's Attic

body: Emmy Delacruz and her best friend, Manuela Guzman, had their routine down even before the first float: gyrate furiously to the deafening bass line for about 30 seconds, then scream: ''Republica Dominicana!'' ''You look around,'' yelled Ms. Delacruz, 18, ''and you can't believe there are this many Dominicans in the whole world!'' To the
title: Dominicans Celebrate Growth in Volume

body: A Brooklyn teen-ager was charged yesterday in the killing of a teacher who tried to break up a bottle-throwing fight, the police said. The youth, Diego Domingues, 16, was arrested yesterday after witnesses identified him as the man who used a baseball bat to kill a substitute teacher, Richard Meehan, during a melee last week near a bodega in Sunset
title: Youth Held In the Killing Of a Teacher

body: There was a time, before the feud, when Blanca Ramirez and Sonia Torres were never apart, their neighbors say. They were friends like that for more than 20 years. Hermanas. Sisters, almost. They double dated. They baby-sat each other's children, bathed them, changed their diapers; Blanca is the godmother of Sonia's oldest boy. When they needed to
title: Street Divided Hatfield-McCoy Style;Feud Escalates, Block Suffers In Brooklyn

body: The white-robed priest who waved incense around the coffin was John Cardinal O'Connor. The dark-suited man who rendered a special eulogy was Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. But the most touching tributes yesterday to Jill Ann Ziemkiewicz, a 23-year-old flight attendant, were more modest and homespun: the laminated snapshots of her that dozens of friends
title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE MOURNING;Tears, Sunflowers, Prayers, Photos, Carnations and More Tears

body: A man walks very slowly next to a chain-link fence topped with razor wire, enclosing a subway yard. In the dust is a broken half-pint liquor bottle and many empty motor-oil containers. Inexplicably, a dollar bill drifts by on a lazy wind. The man is not content simply to know that he is on 37th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues near a subway
title: Tracking and Cataloguing the Wild Flora;A Taxonomist and Volunteers Keep Tabs on Regional Diversity

body: Their days now are bracketed by briefings. In the morning and again in the evening, they listen to Government officials, who stand grimly in the front of a hotel ballroom near Kennedy International Airport and describe what, if anything, has been learned since the last such session. In the long hours in between, the relatives and friends of
title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE FAMILIES;For Families, Few Answers Except the Ones They Fear

body: Shortly after 5 o'clock on a muggy afternoon last week, Connie Lui, spent from a long day poring over ledgers, hopped out of a powder blue Dodge van that rolled along Eighth Avenue in Sunset Park. For more than a year now, Ms. Lui has relied on the army of vans that line Eighth Avenue during rush hour to take her to and from the Chinatown meat
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNSET PARK;Illegal Van Express Overtakes Slow Trains to Chinatown

body: NEW YORK Therapy Called Softball The Ravens, a women's softball team, are the pride of Project Return, a not-for-profit foundation that runs one of New York City's largest drug treatment programs. Part of the women's division of the Therapeutic Community of America League, the Ravens and five other teams -- made up of recovering drug addicts -- bat
title: Metro Digest

body: Two men shot dead by police officers on Thursday night in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, were brothers who had threatened the officers with knives after arguing with each other, the police said yesterday. One man was shot 18 times, the city Medical Examiner's office said. One man was struggling with an officer and was about to stab him when he was shot,
title: Slain Brothers Wielded Knives, Police Say

body: Three men were killed and five injured, one critically, in two shootings that occurred within one block and two hours of each other last night in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, the police said. The first shooting took place about 9:20 when a car carrying at least two men stopped in front of the Sibao Grocery at the corner of 45th Street and
title: 3 Are Killed In 2 Shootings In Brooklyn

body: Art Workshops Jewish Museum 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street (212) 423-3225 Recommended ages: 3 and up Sundays through July 28 Sunday afternoon with Marc Chagall can bring out the red in you. Or the brown, or the blue. A recent trip to see the exhibition "Marc Chagall: 1907-1917" was just the way to get a reluctant boy to paint. This workshop,
title: For Children

body: The Giuliani administration, which last year won new authority to crack down on suspected corruption and Mafia influence at the Fulton Fish Market, is planning to impose the same strict rules on New York City's four other major wholesale produce and meat markets, a top mayoral aide said yesterday. Randy M. Mastro, chief of staff to Mayor Rudolph W.
title: Giuliani Plans to Scrutinize Four Wholesale Markets

body: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS Around the Kitchen Table: An Immigrant Community In 1870, there were seven Chinese immigrants living in Brooklyn. In 1990, according to the census, there were 68,191. This growing community is the subject of the Brooklyn Historical Society's exhibit New Neighbors: Sunset Park's Chinese Community. The society has previously looked
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: MAKING IT WORK 3 At Club Taurino, unabashed bullfight lovers gather to enjoy things Spanish. NEW YORKERS & CO. 4 Haircutters around Astor Place turn the scissors on one another. PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD 11 A fair on Roosevelt Island; an exhibit on the Chinese community of Sunset Park; Shakespeare in the Bronx; buskers invade Wall Street. MOVIE
title: ALSO INSIDE

body: THE KRIEGERS were standing in a hallway of Augustus, their clothing company in Brooklyn, trying to explain why they do not manufacture their suits in sweatshops or in China or Honduras or Taiwan or anyplace else where labor is so much cheaper than in New York City. "I guess," Arlene Krieger said, "we do not speak the language." She was not
title: Metro Matters;Maker of Suits Sticks to Vow: No Sweatshop

body: The Transit Authority plans to begin operating a few short subway lines without conductors by late summer -- a first in the system's 92 years -- and the authority's president said yesterday that it was just the beginning of a move toward one-person train crews around the city. Trains now operate with two-person crews, an operator and a conductor,
title: Savings Plan to Cut Crews In Subways

body: WHEREVER Greeks gather, a kaffenion can usually be found. It's a rough place where men gather to talk and down cups of coffee and shots of ouzo. When approximately 350,000 Greeks came to the United States between 1900 and 1920, they brought the kaffenion with them. No one knows exactly how it happened, but Dan Georgakas, who teaches labor and
title: The Kaffenion Connection: How the Greek Diner Evolved

body: A 26-year-old Brooklyn woman pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree murder in the beating death of her 3-year-old daughter. Sara Munoz, an illegal immigrant from Mexico, admitted in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn that she had hit the child with a stick from 7 to 15 times last July, saying she had done so because the girl had defecated, the
title: Mother Fatally Beat Girl, 3

body: Could a feisty middle-aged white woman who knows nothing about sports mold a losing black basketball team into high school champions? "Sunset Park," a sentimental comedy that shows a genuine fondness for its characters, would like to think so. This good-natured pipe dream of a movie, set in the wilds of Brooklyn, deals onlq glancingly with the
title: FILM REVIEW;How an Unlikely Coach Inspires Her Basketball Team

body: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract. MANHATTAN CHELSEA $683,345 147 West 15th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 2,400-sq.-ft. co-op in a loft building; elevator, chef's kitchen, 12 1/2-ft. ceilings, 3 exposures; maintenance
title: Residential Resales

body: WHEREVER Greeks gather, a kaffenion can usually be found. It's a rough place where men gather to talk and down cups of coffee and shots of ouzo. When approximately 350,000 Greeks came to the United States between 1900 and 1920, they brought the kaffenion with them. No one knows exactly how it happened, but Dan Georgakas, who teaches labor and
title: The Kaffenion Connection: How the Greek Diner Evolved

body: A police detective was slashed across the face with a box cutter yesterday while he and his partner were trying to break up a dispute among three men in Brooklyn, the police said. The detective, Michael Johnson, 28, was about to enter the New Sun Lumber Yard at 756 Eighth Avenue in Sunset Park when he and his partner, Detective Gerald Ahern, saw
title: Detective Is Slashed as He Stops a Fight

body: New York City's effort to shore up the crumbling Manhattan Bridge will take about 10 years longer and almost $300 million more than officials had predicted when the repairs began in 1982. The repairs, which have cut two subway connections between Manhattan and Brooklyn for periods of more than 10 years each and have clogged roads and highways in
title: Neglect of Manhattan Bridge Takes Toll in Time and Money

body: Medical insurance is often hard for many people to obtain. But relatives and friends of some teamsters' union officials in Brooklyn had no trouble getting it improperly, according to Federal investigators. The four top leaders of the union, Local 1205, were removed yesterday after an independent investigative panel charged that about 30 relatives
title: 4 Teamsters Officials Ousted Over Insurance Fraud Charge

body: The double-digit decline in crime that New York City has enjoyed in the last two years is slowing, police statistics show, with an increase in rapes citywide and a growing number of murders, burglaries and robberies in several neighborhoods. For the city as a whole, reports of serious crime declined 9 percent in the first three months of this year.
title: Drop in Crime Slows to 9% In the Quarter

body: The job requirements for Poet Laureate of the Borough of Brooklyn are fairly simple: you have to be a published poet recognized by your peers, and you have to have some connection to Kings County. Preferably, you call it home. But the job description of the unpaid three-year appointment depends on whom you ask, even among the literary cadre
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;What Makes a Borough Bard?

body: A Place to Eat, Drink and Smoke Cigars Michael Ayoub, the owner and chef of Cucina on Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, smokes cigars only occasionally, but appreciates one after a good meal. That, he said, is why the cigar will figure so prominently in his new restaurant, Mike and Tony's Bar and Grill, opposite Cucina at 239 Fifth Avenue in
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.

body: For more than 30 years, the Food and Drug Administration has been conducting tests on consumer goods from a rundown warehouse in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, that freezes in the winter, boils in the summer and leaks when it rains. Despite the laboratory's poor condition, it houses state-of-the-art research equipment like a mass spectrometer and capillary
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JAMAICA;F.D.A. Lab Goes Collegiate

body: Transit officials took issue yesterday with a harsh assessment by Federal investigators that faulted top management for a subway crash in Brooklyn last year and said that while the system is generally safe, accidents are inevitable because the system is antiquated and heavily dependent on human performance. But in a tacit admission that, as Federal
title: Officials Dispute Federal Findings on Subway Safety

body: Rising shoals of mud threaten the economic engine that is New York Harbor, where 4,500 ships a year carry $60 billion worth of goods and generate tens of thousands of jobs. As always, thousands of tons of riverborne silt sift into the harbor's shipping channels each day. For 80 years, the soupy mud was just a nuisance here, but now it threatens the
title: SHALLOW WATERS: A special report.;Curbs on Silt Disposal Threaten Port of New York as Ships Grow Larger

body: Danny Coronel, a bartender from Elmhurst, Queens, lost his telephone when a former friend used it for calls to Hong Kong -- $1,900 worth. Jose Ramos, a livery-cab driver, and his wife, Jackie, never had a phone, even though they moved to Washington Heights in Manhattan from the Dominican Republic more than two years ago. "We didn't have anything in
title: Phone Plan Is Attracting Immigrants In New York

body: Vyacheslav Kirillovich Ivankov, a bearded and compactly built man, spends his days in a Brooklyn jail preparing his autobiography -- his version of a supposedly heroic struggle against communist tyranny in the Soviet Union. As Mr. Ivankov labors on his literary efforts, his trial lawyer, Barry I. Slotnick, is preparing a defense that he says will
title: Trial Looms for Man Held as Emigre Godfather

body: NEW YORK CITY Murder-Suicide After Probation Just hours after being sentenced under a plea bargain to probation for attacking his girlfriend's cousin with a baseball bat, a Bronx man shot and killed his girlfriend as their 3-month-old baby sat in her lap, the police said. The man then turned the gun on himself, the police said, leaving the baby
title: METRO DIGEST

body: When MIPS Technologies, one of the country's largest microchip manufacturers, started a nationwide contest to find a school that could most benefit from a corporate donation, it fully expected principals to put computers, software and other high-tech equipment at the top of their wish lists. But the application that impressed the company most was
title: School's Corporate Rescue: Cash for Books and Desks

body: No charges were filed against the driver of a vehicle that struck and killed a New York City police officer on Saturday, officials said. The officer, identified as Charles Oddo, 33, was struck about 2:15 P.M. on the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn, said a police spokesman, Doram Tamari. He was diverting traffic away from an oil spill on the Gowanus
title: Killed Officer Is Identified

body: Imagine awaiting selection as a juror in a pleasant and comfortable assembly room, with a telephone near at hand and a handsome lounge nearby. Perkins Eastman Architects of Manhattan, architect for the new Queens Civil Courthouse in construction in Jamaica, promises these pleasures and more when the courthouse opens, probably in June of next year.
title: POSTINGS: 20 Housing and Civil Courtrooms;New Courts In Queens Halfway Complete

body: Anderson Cooper recalls being stuck at an airport in Rwanda in 1994, weighed down by luggage and video camera, and watching enviously as a CBS News crew left a plane, got into a waiting car and sped off. "At that point, the highest priority in life was a vehicle," he said. At that point, Mr. Cooper was chief foreign correspondent for Channel One,
title: TELEVISION;ABC Sends a Young Point of View Into the Field

body: A transit worker was struck and killed by a Coney Island-bound B train yesterday in a Brooklyn subway tunnel. The train was on the express tracks, just beyond the Union Street and Fourth Avenue station in Sunset Park, when its emergency brakes tripped about 11:30 A.M., said Termain Garden, a Transit Authority spokesman. The train operator got out
title: Subway Worker Hit and Killed on Tracks

body: New York State has sold off a prison and a highway to raise quick cash. Now the city wants to sell off one of its most familiar fixtures -- its parking meters. In a complicated plan that is still short on detail, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed shifting the maintenance and operation of the city's 68,000 parking meters to a private
title: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: REVENUES;Parking Meters May Be Sold To a Company

body: It was a night for the insiders and a night that politicians who normally do not agree on much came together to anoint a candidate. And it was the night after a night on which Democratic loyalists pounded on doors in this sprawling Brooklyn district, lining up proxy votes from those who would be unable to attend the meeting at which Seymour Lachman
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;Ever the Loyal Democrat, Lachman Reaps His Reward

body: New York City buses have long been notorious for the black soot many of them spew out of their exhaust pipes. Now, as the Transit Authority is starting to convert the fleet to run on cleaner-burning fuels, several state legislators and environmentalists say the efforts fall far short of what is needed. They are urging the Metropolitan
title: Buses Using Natural Gas Do Well in Pilot Program

body: IT seems the simplest of props: footprints are painted on the floor, a baseball bat is suspended by wires, home plate is just below. On the wall behind looms a life-size photograph of Jackie Robinson. You, the visitor, put your feet in Robinson's footsteps and step up to the plate. You grasp the bat. Suddenly, the roar of the crowd materializes all
title: Brooklyn History, Inning by Inning
